The NAC Protocol (Updated December, 2022)

Morning

*1200mg NAC
*Oregano Oil (min. 40mg Carvacrol)
*Black Seed Oil (1 teaspoon)

Night

*600mg NAC
*Oregano Oil (min. 40mg Carvacrol)
*Black Seed Oil (1 teaspoon)

Continue daily for a minimum of two months and count out 3 weeks with no die off symptoms prior to moving to the next step.

Maintenance Protocol
__________

Morning

*600mg NAC
*500mg Slo Niacin (nicotinic acid)
*100mg Pterostilbene
*Black Seed Oil (1 teaspoon)

Night

*500mg Slo Niacin
*100mg Pterostilbene
*Black Seed Oil (1 teaspoon)

After every 3 weeks on the maintenance protocol, take 1 week off. Continue to use black seed oil during the off cycle.

Fungal die off symptoms may include :

Tiredness, exhaustion, muscle soreness, increased chest or nasal discharge, cold or flu like symptoms, cold sores, headaches, rash, acne, irritability, change in stool frequency, volume or color; increased urination, bloated stomach, cramps, increased gas.

OREGANO DOSING GUIDE

For each morning and night dose you need a minimum of 40mg Carvacrol. Do not buy a product unless it is listed. Most products are steam distilled but you will want to confirm that.

If your chosen oregano oil contains a higher amount of carvacrol (60mg+ per cap) you'll want to start with 1 cap morning, 1 cap night. If each cap contains less than 40mg, take 2 morning 2 night.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
this is a recipe I use to make my own "bread"/rolls. It's not sourdough by any means, but it's not bad. this will make one "loaf" or 5-6 rolls.

1/2 cup coconue flour
5 Tablespoons psyllium husk powder
2 tsp. baking powder
1 tsp salt
1/3 cup protein powder (whey protein isolate)
2-3 Tablespoons apple cider vinegar
4 eggs
1 cup boiling water

Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F.
Combine the flour, psyllium powder, baking powder, protein powder, and salt. Mix until dry ingredients are well combined. Add in the eggs and vinegar and mix until a thick dough. Slowly, add boiling water. Mix until well combined and dough firms up.

Form into 4 to 5 rolls or one loaf and place onto a greased baking sheet (or loaf pan). Bake for 60 minutes (if using a loaf pan, it will take longer to bake--about 1 1/2 hours). Remove from the oven and allow the bread to cool completely.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33898418
The easiest way to start with astrology is by getting an automated online natal chart reading from astrolabe.com and cafeastrology and astro-seek. Read what they say about your own placements, and then recognize the accuracy with respect to your own character.

The knowledge of astrology preceeds thus.
You learn what the signs mean.
You learn what the planets in a sign means.
You learn what the planets mean.
That's the beginner route.
Then you learn what aspects mean.
Then you learn what the houses mean.
And then from there you learn more various minutiae.

There are other things you'll pick up along the way. What the symbols mean, for example.

There's no proper course /x/ has charted to learning astrology. I myself have learned it over the course of over a decade piecemeal on and off. Picking up the basics is actually easy, simple, and quick. It's sorting out all the misinfo and disinfo that's liberally sprinkled about the educative material that will take tremendous time and effort. The modern state of astrology is plagued with niggling inaccuracies in matters of detail even though they give generally correct information.

It is, absolutely. You can do it in stages, I do when I am having trouble believing the complete picture. That said Neville's method of skipping to the end is brilliant if you can pull it off- you don't need to manage every stage of the desire(and you shouldn't, there are more delays and chances for failure) and the ways it manifest will probably be better than what you would come up with.

Keep in mind when you say "Human Nature" what I think you are really saying is "That's how we are usually taught to think." You'll see a lot in these threads that we are all deconstructing what we were taught because we are specifically taught not to use this method. Only the weirdos that weren't with the program(and were punished for it) may have avoided that.

>>33900590
Meant to say read Neville Goddard to put your mind at ease. Hemi sync and binaural beats all could work, it’s really just based on your own experience, preferences, and whether you allow it to work or not

Prior to even doing sats however, you should strive to gain control over your anxious thoughts during waking. Meditation to still the mind can help with this. When you meditate simply attempt to maintain focus on your breath or some object. You will see firsthand how your attention switches to the thoughts you have. This is fine and normal. Observe the thoughts and let them go. Give no emotional energy to them. Look at them as just things that exist in your mind then return your attention to your breath or object.

You need to get to a point where you can look at a thought, feel it out, and let it go throughout your day. This is not easy as I’m sure you are aware but it will get easier over time. You also need to get to a point where you internalize this concept: you are not your thoughts, and your thoughts are not you. You just happen to create them and it’s always within your power to give thoughts your attention even if it doesn’t seem like it. Your current habit is giving attention to thoughts born out of worry and fear. You will be able to break the habit by observing the thoughts without placing judgements on them. This is also paramount for a good mental diet

Do consistent meditation and sats and you’ll be able to quell inner turmoil and doubts that arise and also bring your dream life from imagination into reality

Give no power to your immediately observable reality. The whole point of the Law of Assumption is to realize that the observable 3D reality is a reflection of your internal world. Rescind the power you give to the 3D and give it your imagination. This gets easier as your subconscious gets the memo. This is quite difficult and in complete contrast to what we learn from society, which is why Neville stresses this point over and over again

It's rough when you have to work under the gun Anon. This Anon>>33901467 has the right of it down to the that we are taught LOA has no power over observable reality.

Having been in situations like yours before I would start with basics and work up to what you currently want. Your current need is likely giving you strong lust for result and that kills the manifestation for most people.

If you are religious I would pray for a miracle with your SATS sessions and during the day. Feel what you need, ask for it and use your faith to believe it will happen.

If you are not religious do small things you can believe and manifest and then ramp up from those successes. A good one is "Everything is going to turn out right for me in the end" or "I am on the right path, I can accomplish this" or "That was my reality, this is my new reality"

I did not know about LOA at the time and I was not able to force specific outcomes but by believing things would be all right everything did mysteriously work out.

Blessings Anon and good luck- focus on whether you are feeling the sense that the SATS and other workings have set and if they are let them go so they can work- the last part can be exceptionally hard, and as I have posted here I have at times had to give up in complete hopelessness for the manifest to come...but it always has.

A metaphysical doctrine that almost every religion upholds is this: if you don't believe in the right God, or belief system that gets you successfully to that God, you have NO ONE BUT YOURSELF TO BLAME, because, you heard of that God at some point but didn't follow Him.
My problem with this is that, as a Christian, I have heard many Christian doctrines and have rejected MANY of them. I reject nontrinitarianism, I reject Calvinism, I think I reject universalism, I reject the doctrine of the Jehovah's Witnesses and I reject the doctrine of the Mormons.
Some of you might remember on the show South Park, the only people in heaven were Mormons. Because according to God, "they were the only ones who got it right." At my Evangelical church, they preach pretty heavily that atheists go to Hell because "they choose to reject God," but curiously they also tend to say that the Jehovah's Witnesses are damned to Hell because "they choose to reject Him as He is and they therefore accept a false doctrine."
But isn't that kind of a double-edged sword? What if, for the sake of argument, these doctrines we've rejected are actually right? Even though we're Christian, God would be able to ask us, "Why didn't you believe this stuff in the way I intended you to? You had the opportunity to listen to Jehovah's Witnesses and renounce non-denominational Christianity/trinitarian Christianity, so why didn't you?"
Doesn't the concept of, "It was all on you to believe the right thing" completely negate the non-works based salvation that most Christians and non-apostates hold onto?

>>33900352
>monad
According to WikiPedia

In functional programming, a monad is a software design pattern with a structure that combines program fragments (functions) and wraps their return values in a type with additional computation. In addition to defining a wrapping monadic type, monads define two operators: one to wrap a value in the monad type, and another to compose together functions that output values of the monad type (these are known as monadic functions). General-purpose languages use monads to reduce boilerplate code needed for common operations (such as dealing with undefined values or fallible functions, or encapsulating bookkeeping code). Functional languages use monads to turn complicated sequences of functions into succinct pipelines that abstract away control flow, and side-effects.[1][2]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33806643
>How do i know if it's lucid dreaming or not?
You recognize a "full blown lucid dream" by your mental clarity, not what you're able to do. In full lucid dreams you have the same kind of sharp thinking as in real life, able to fully self-reflect and process thoughts as in waking life. In what you call dreams ibetween it's more like you're a zombie with a vague notion that there are no consequences for your actions.

>>33807184
If you're religious, you might benefit from thinking lucid dreaming is some kind of magic phenomena, since it will make it feel more real. If you want to just DILD, do the boring basic shit like keeping a dream journal, reality checks, and MILD before bed.

posts.com:
well gents, new year new goals. something i wish to take seriously this year is something i've come to call "wake-sleeping", although i suppose a more fitting name might simply be "lucid sleeping".

the concept is quite simple: remain aware whenever the body sleeps. it would certainly be similar to WILD, except it takes place at bed time, and ends when you would normally wake up; the ultimate goal being, to completely and entirely decouple consciousness from sleep. the most advanced form of this practice, theoretically, would result in one who never lapses in consciousness, 24/7 awareness.

i've made some progress on making this work, but it's obviously hard. it is certainly possible, however, and so i remain confident in its feasibility, but the trial and error is long and grueling.

i will keep updates in these threads as meaningful developments occur, as this intersects plainly with lucid dreaming (engaging in this practice successfully would have a side effect of making ALL dreams lucid).

I accidentally went directly into a lucid dream without even trying
>Woke up in the middle of the night, probably because I took 2 valerian root capsules before bed
>Can't really get back to sleep
>Figure I'll just do some imagination and visualization
>Spend an unspecified amount of time focusing while imagining things, it was a long time
>Ok, time to go to bed
>Lie on my back and relax
>Hypnagogia starts almost immediately, white fuzz forms into snow falling over a river during nighttime
>Realize what is happening, imagine where I want to be
>I am in my house, it's the middle of the day, for whatever reason I am short, as tall as a toddler
>There are people yelling outside (my room is on the second story), I look down at them, my relatives have arrived in a couple trucks, decide to go out of my room and look around the house as a small person
>My cousin is outside of my door, she is much taller than me
>Can see up her skirt, slap her ass and run past her, she doesn't notice
>Walk around my house for a bit, neat seeing how it is from this tall
>I lose focus and the dream shifts into black. At this moment I don't put in the effort to shift it back into something and just wake up
So overall I knew I was dreaming and could control what I was doing but for whatever reason I had the feeling that I should wake up and sleep properly, so I did. I'm sure if I was actually planning to lucid dream I would have stayed in there but I was tired and it didn't really matter at the time.
I'm theorizing that spending a bunch of time just "imagining" stuff and getting lost in your fantasy world will vastly improve the chances of entering the right state to do this, this was actually the first time for me being in the hypnagogic state and I didn't even try for it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33878876 >>33878852
your mind doesn't fall asleep all at once, it follows a very specific route
as you relax at first proprioception will be turned off [your ability to feel the position of your limbs] then nociception and thermoception turn off [your ability to sense pain and sensing temperature] and finally kinesthesicepion and equilibrioception will turn off [your ability to feel motion and your orientation]
while there are more things that turn off after these two, those two are almost a perfect setup to either fall asleep right there or just enter a wild
i used to have a really hard time falling asleep until i figured this out dayo

>>33880358
that's a strange question dayo
when the first one turns off you will only feel points of contact, normally when you put your hand behind your back you know its there even though you can't see it, so when proprioception is turned off you would only feel the hand if its making contact with your back
when thermoception is off you either won't feel warm or cold anymore or you will feel really warm even if you really aren't
kinesthesicepion feels like you're in motion, usually spinning or falling

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33887289
Aphantasia has nothing to do with dreaming. Dreams are not created in your minds eye, they are created using the same process that you use in your waking life but without the external stimuli. They are more accurately compared to hallucinations than imagination. That's why you require sleep paralysis to stop you from moving and why your real eyes follow the movement of your dream eyes.

Also it's worth pointing out almost all studies that have tested it have shown that aphantasia can be fixed with simple practice. Don't be one of these people that just wallows in a completelypyxshk preventable "handicap".

Easiest I've found was imagining the sensation of being forced to move, so don't literally move but imagine a motion that would force you out of bed, like
>pulling yourself up and out by a rope dangling above you
>rolling hard to either side
>falling
For me pulling myself up I can't do the rope thing but I've almost made it by trying to levitate up and out but like a thick glue I snap back into myself and fall deep asleep
For rolling, the one time it worked I didn't realize it did so I just went into the bathroom (false awakening type of thing) and then yet again deep sleep
Falling though worked better, imagine how it feels to stand upright and then fall backwards and tumblr upside down, that took me from mildly awake/bordering sleep directly into a dream and it was cool as fuck desu it was like I fell backwards into a wormhole and it wooshed me around to some destination, even if it landed me right in my bedroom I'd have known it worked because why tf did I fall backwards through my bed
I haven't had anything close to success since though and that was months ago

>how do i redpill my normie gf on the covid hoax?

Run us through why you think it's a hoax. As "cleanly" and consisely as possible just make your case.
Like, just real quick: give us your best bulletin points on why you think it's a hoax, where/how you came to that conclusion(don't need specific citations, just a vague/general source), and then a brief "because of these things, this can't be true, and that's why they're wrong."

Because if you're going to convince anyone of anything you basically need three things:
1. You need to be able to replicate or recite their opinion. Full stop. If you can't do that then you can't deboonk them (because you don't know what they believe in enough to repeat it) and they won't believe you because they'll think you're bad faith.
2. You need to be able to establish a body of recipts. Where you get your information from, why it's credible, etc..
3. Finally, you need to be able to compare, contrast, to root out inconsistent details, find motives, detective work basically.

First and foremost though, and this is a big cheat code: ask people, "what do I need to convince you?" And then work backward.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>33894023
While theoretically the term communism could have been used by Pike, as it was popularized by Marx and Engels in the 1840s ahead of the publication of the Communist Manifesto, the roots of the Russian Revolution did not form until the 1890s, some 20 years after the letter was allegedly written and when Pike was on his last legs. The reader must question whether he could have been privy to the outcome of the Russian workers’ movement before those workers themselves had ever heard of Marx or formed the movement to oppose their masters? And if he was, how could he have such foresight to suggest a World War could simply be brought about and that it could be controlled in such a manner to accomplish his goals? It’s not only highly unlikely but there is nothing of substance to suggest it actually happened. No testimony from anybody else associated with Pike, no other correspondence or writings from Pike himself - literally nothing other than this alleged letter. It should also be noted that other than the general enlightenment movement the only "Illuminati" organization documented within decades of the time-frame of the letter was the Bavarian Illuminati which officially disbanded in 1785. Though conspiracy theories flourish to this day and the term is used in the abstract, serious accusations of the group’s secret continuation had died out at least 50 years before the letter was allegedly written. Out of all the verified Pike literature, only Morals & Dogma makes a fleeting and abstract use of the term Illuminati and this certainly ins’t in he context of some all powerful secret society. So if Pike believed a war must take place for the Illuminati, who are they and what evidence is there to support that they existed and he was a member? Of course some irrational proponents of the "letter" will say they’re a secret. But if they are such a well kept secret, how do (you) know they are/were real? It’s unfounded speculation at best.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33894023
>>33898207
Furthermore, the rest of the "letter" is also extremely dubious. Terms like Fascism, Nazism and Zionism were never used in Pike's lifetime. Zionism as a word was coined in 1890 by Nathan Birnbaum and would not take root for several more years. There is no record of Pike knowing or meeting Birnbaum or having any connection to the Zionist movement. The ideological roots of Fascism were only in their infancy during Pike's final years, and the term was not used publicly until Mussolini took his position in the 1920s. The term Nazism did not emerge until the 1930s with the rise of Germany's National Socialist party. Unless Pike can predict the future or was the God himself, it would seem this "letter" is nothing more than a modern forgery.

>>33891056
Sorry for being harsh, but that's kind of dumb. If you're going to be talking about masculine and active signs then it makes no sense to ignore the traditional designation. If Sagittarius is the sign of the wanderer or adventurer, Gemini is the sign of the trickster or "manipulator" (in the objective rather than the social sense). It's not a coincidence that Gemini rules the arms. As the third sign in the zodiac, Gemini also invokes the symbolism of the number three, which symbolises the emergence of self-awareness and the manipulation and control over other things. A lot of the active and masculine archetypes you find in modern fiction, like the lovable rogue, for example, can be much more closely identified with Gemini than with Sagittarius. At its best, Gemini is an insightful and strategic sign, and at its worst it is a cunning and malicious one. It seems unfair to me to reduce it only to the ideas of superficiality and unreliability - it entirely depends on the situation and the manifestation (like which house and what planets are involved). In mutable-type situations I think you'd be hard pressed to find a sign that does better than Gemini.

pic rel is Pessoa's chart
>>THE DOCTRINE OF TRANSITS

>The horoscope doesn't describe what there is before birth, nor what there is after death, although you can admit that aspects (directions) in regression, and in succession of death, can indicate certain phenomena external in relation to life, so to say, pre-natal and post-mortal of the individual. This, however, is dubious.
>Life is essentially action, and what the horoscope indicates is the action there is in the life of the native. There's three things not to look for in the horoscope: (1) the fundamental qualities of the individual, as to his intimite degree; (2) the social starting point of his life; (3) what results of him, and the life that he had, after death. Everything, but this, does the horoscope include and define.
>Let's not be amazed that it is uninteresting and ordinary the horoscope of a great artist that was only celebrated after death: the horoscope will indicate artistic qualities (to a degree we cannot measure) and will indicate obscurity. Everything will be indicated in abstract; only our own foresight will realize it. (Such is the meaning of Ptolemy's first apothem.)
>Better exemplifying: a horoscope of a dramatic poet may be determined as it also may , within the same horoscope, be indicated a certain fame and a certain profit. That aside, it can be the horoscope of Shakespeare or that of a dramatic poet of inferior note, that, in the era that he lived in, had had a life, as far as fame and profit, identical or similar to that of Shakespeare. The horoscope reveals, little more or less, what he worlds sees. Never must we forget this detail of utmost importance. Without it we'll make nothing of astrology.

>Honestly think the auspicious future I can have depends entirely on me
There's a position within astrology schools called astrological determinism. Some Hellenistic astrologers (there's Vedic, Chinese and several other types of astrological traditions in case you were not aware) you will most likely get to know, like Firmicus Maternus, Vettius Valens and Marcus Manilius, held that stance. Here's an excerpt from Marcus Manilius' Astronomica:
>Fate rules the world, all things stand fixed by its immutable laws, and the long ages are assigned a predestined course of events. At birth our death is sealed and our end is consequent upon our beginning. Fate is the source of riches and kingdoms and the more frequent poverty; by fate are men at birth given their skills and characters, their merits and defects, their losses and gains. None can renounce what is bestowed or possess what is denied; no man by prayer may seize fortune if it demur, or escape if it draw nigh: each one must bear his appointed lot.

Even if such view is incorrect, there's still good reasons to think free will is merely an illusion but getting into it is not relevant to this conversation.

There's no use addressing the rest because you'll stumble with the evidence supporting those statements sooner rather than later in the learning process.

The universe on its largest timescales is a story of ever complexifying behavior.

>start with nothing
>create a burst of energy
>energy congeals in to basic atoms like hydrogen
>hydrogen gas clouds form stars
>stars form more complicated elements
>stars explode, restarting to the place 3 steps above, but with newer heavier elements, and with other stars still in the mix
>eventually planets and asteroids form
>planets and asteroids have similar cycles of birth, formation, and death
>eventually life forms
>life has its own birthing, forming, and dying
>life eventually gives rise to sentience
>sentience produces cycles within the cycles of life, and even greater cycles through the passage of knowledge through time
>eventually sentient beings form the next level of emergence
>forcing matter to compute
>eventually forcing matter to become alive, without obvious biological counterparts

Sentience exists to form the next level of emergent behavior. Also note that each level of emergence has its own cycles, but those cycles are contextualized in to grander cycles of the lower levels of emergence. This is the interlocking wheels of time. The recursive cycles of existence.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33902315
>When I touch a fish, why am I touching the perception of a fish rather than just touching a fish?
Because you don't know what "fish" means other than your perceptions of it. Aside from the scientific view that reduces it down to something called "matter" or "particles" which is still an unknown.

The simplest way I can try to explain this in an intellectual sense is the following:
You're basically claiming no axiom of reality can be known, but are you sure about that? There's no axiom that _science_ can find (and there's a good reason for that), but for the moment just ask yourself what a TRUE axiom of reality itself would look like.

What if, just maybe, it looks like something you know without ever having to learn it. Something so simple that you take it for granted and literally is the foundation of everything you know or ever can know. But your mind ignores the axiom because it never had to be defined for the mind... And it never had to be defined because it has no definition, because that's exactly what an axiom IS.
Then instead of saying that evolution created beings to avoid harmful things (which could have been done without any feeling at all) and the very real sensation of "pain" is just an illusory side-effect... What if instead the truth was that evolution USED a feature of reality called "pain" to make creatures avoid harmful things.

I mean hell, even in the highest levels of physics the very concept of "matter" is almost totally meaningless. It's all waves of probability at this point, and what does that mean?
It means probability that you'll _perceive_ an outcome.

So when you touch the fish the reason your feeling is the ground and not the concept of "fish" is because you already know what the feeling is without having any concept at all. Feeling is its own definition.
The "fish" concept depends on your experience of it, and of "mind".
But experience alone requires nothing but itself to be known. Like an axiom.

i encountered a sasquatch last year in the northern cascades while hiking alone.
i took a video of it.
then after that i was overcome with dread so i ran and somehow got lost 3 miles up this mountain for over an hour, slipping and sliding down this steep grade, holding on to branches and bushes.
And while i was lost there was about a dozen tree knocks in total, following me from the left and right.
anyways, i sat down finally and asked in my mind “sasquatch, can you help me find the trail? i’m lost and just want to go to back to camp”
i had nothing to lose, i just thought that and sent it away and kept walking.

so as i’m heading down, holding on to branches because of the steepness of the slope, and i hear this massive ROAR from over my right shoulder.
it reverberated my entire chest and body and was so terrifying, i instinctively turned left to get away from the noise.
i was too scared to even look back, it sounded like a fucking lion, and i’m heading left now instead of down.
about 100 yards later i reach a small cliff and find the trail.

As i’m walking down the trail, i’m looking over to the right where i was lost, and the mountain gave way to huge steep gravely and loose shale cliffs. if i had continued even another 100 yards, i would’ve easily slipped and fallen to my death or serious injury.

so whatever made that roar that forced me to turn left at that exact moment saved my life.

I feel incredibly humbled and lucky to have had this experience. i got a video of it, it showed itself to me, because right before the encounter i was singing songs about sasquatch and how i want to see one.
These things are real, and they are more than animals.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33897139
I will concur with this. I have found many ways to fly or float in dreams, but the most common and easiest to work with involve motions or principles that are rooted in reality or easy to grasp in the moment - like pretending to swim in the air or flapping ones wings like a bird.

I've also become very good at moving objects with my mind in a way that a comic-book or anime character might, specifically moving stuff towards my hands in a way one might recall a yoyo (I love yoyos) or moving it around as though my arm were some sort of wand directing it where to go. However, all feats of wonder in dreams lucid or otherwise are tricky in that they generally require absolute faith you're able to do them when you attempt them. If I am tricked even for a moment that I "believe I can't" or if the effect falters at all, the instant I lose motivation, it stops working. I've trained now to keep trying; so that steels my resolve.

I think this is why many newbies and even relatively excited lucid dreamers get a power once and then let it go quickly and can't do it again - without the motivation trick and good recall, it's a bit like catching sand until you get a good foundation. Many might attribute their powers in dreams to gifts and lessons etc and I think that's a marvelous way to reframe the trick of motivation (because you will remember you were "given" that power and own it) but in reality, at the most basic level, any well-experienced lucid dreamer knows that literally anything can be done in a dream purely by wishing it so. I can close my eyes and start a dream over from scratch, direct it exactly as I want it, teleport, or summon anything.

It gets boring if I do this, but it's great to be able to stop a nightmare. Great to start a bad dream off right. Next time try closing your eyes mid-dream and saying out loud something like "I'm going to be in front of _____" like your old school or maybe your old house. If you trust what I said, it will work. Cheers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
We gather in these generals to discuss our experiences, memories, and connection with Mother Lilith, as well as give other anons who are interested or would like to learn more about Her information or advice.

>Practices or rituals associated with Lilith?
This differs from person to person, but common approaches include giving energy to one of her sigils, chanting her enn, working with sexual spirits, doing what you think she would do, making offerings of incense/chocolate/tea, or simply praying.
While some people might feel the most comfortable engaging with her in a worshipful manner, blind faith is discouraged. It's always important to think and make decisions for oneself, and as such, Lilith guides us to understand things for ourselves.

>Books
- Liber Lilith by Donald Tyberson: https://www.pdfdrive.com/liber-lilith-a-gnostic-grimoire-e185231845.html
A Gnostic Grimoire and Novel. Beware that this book is rather dark, and some have mentioned attracting unwanted attention by reading it.
- Embracing Lilith by Mark H Williams: No PDF available online, but it's worth the price of admission.
Split into three sections, it covers accounts of working with the Goddess and her place in history, a fictional account of her origins written from her perspective, and a Grimoire.
- Lilith: Dark Feminine Archetype by Asenath Mason: https://pdfcoffee.com/lilith-dark-feminine-archetype-2-pdf-free.html
This one is a collection of writings by various peoples, with a brief but fairly thorough history at the beginning. There's a lot of random poetry in there; not useful for an occultist, but decent for an admirer.
- Lilith: Goddess of Sitra Ahra: https://zeitenundformen.files.wordpress.com/2014/01/lilith-goddess-of-sitra-ahrab-t-p.pdf
Contains a ton of aspects with associated variety of sigils.

>Videos

https://youtu.be/75bnMRPRiDk

>>33848290
I'd suggest that everyone who meditates or wants to start meditating to ask himself the question: Why am I meditating/Why I want to meditate?
So yeah, ask yourself that question.

Ask yourself: Why I want to open my chakras or manipulate energy?

I'm suggesting this because people get into meditation to either chase illusions and other ego-stuff (like goals) or to try and escape from illusions (fears, trauma etc), I think that this is wrong and that meditation should be used for the exact opposite: To realize that all of that are illusions and nothing more.

I'd suggest to just sit and be aware of your body sensations, of your body being there and breathing, not analyzing it or controlling it but totally letting it go and just watching it. This is the basis of the meditative state: Being aware.

But don't put words into it, don't make goals, just do it everyday and stay there.
Depending on who you are this may take some time.

And lastly to also answer your question: You "open chakras" by focusing on them, yeah, meditation is a physical practice not a mental one, you sit to sense and feel so just sit and feel the chakras.

However I'd suggest that first you sit to silence the mind by being still and aware.
Good luck.

>>33853135
>>33853173
There is no division between mindfulness and meditation. Mindfulness is a word that was taken from western spiritual traditions to translate the word "Sati", and it was re-adopted by western society for largely marketing purposes. It's a cozy word. Really, meditation (samadhi) is a focused application of mindfulness (sati). There is no meditation without mindfulness; samma samadhi is the result of samma sati. The Satipatthana sutta is the frame within which all other meditation methods occur in. To be mindful is to keep something in mind, and in Buddhism that's within the framework of the four satipatthana.

I haven't been trained in Zen but I have experience serving retreats at Thai Forest monasteries, where I did read some books on Zazen... the gist I got was that we "just sit to sit" or "sitting is good for nothing". While I can't say how accurate my understanding is, I think this is helpful for times when you get too caught up in goals to the point where you're stressing yourself out, in which case it may be wise to just get back to the bare bones: sitting. But doing that for a while, your mind gets a bit listless or confused, in which case it's helpful to remember why you're practicing in the first place. But sometimes to go deep you have to put aside the part of the mind which is constructing goals and reasons for focusing attention. In a way you have to "just do it". Think Solid Snake in Metal Gear Solid: "Don't think, shoot!"

But in any case, there is mindfulness: remembering to "just sit" or remembering the 16 steps of Anapanasati. You need to read your own mind, so to speak, to see what's good for you. But mindfulness is always there until the end. Sometimes we just get too self conscious about it (which is what the mindfulness industry seems to profit off of).

>>33848290
One of the best uses of meditation is training focused contemplation. You do this through sitting, eyes closed, breathing, and every time you stop paying attention to your breath, you recognize it and pull your attention back to your breathing. It starts with that. Eventually, feel free to let yourself off the leash a little and mentally wander around during your meditation. Something to be cautious of is accidentally developing a dissociative disorder. Be mindful of when that feeling starts to develop and work through it in a healthy way. If you navigate that properly, you have crossed a really powerful milestone in building your skill. If you don't arrive at that point, you haven't been meditating long enough or seriously enough. It's worth getting into, but don't let it consume you. Meditation for me has been at its most beautiful when it feels spontaneous and unplanned. It's ugly when you treat it like it's something you have to pencil in: "oh it's time for my 5 minute 4:00 PM meditation!" When it's just like "hmmm I feel like this is a good time to meditate" that's when I tend to have my best sessions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33857923
There's a point in that kind of goal-less practice where you're actually kind of just feeding whatever is going on, if you aren't considering your input in the experience. It's like having the TV turned to static and just letting it sit like that forever. Giving your mind an object to focus on and refine, such as the breath "energy", gets you deeper.

But being aware of those things is crucial - you just need to stop giving them input if they're causing too much movement or darker states of mind. Instead of seeing thoughts just as some things which happen, see how they arise due to things within your control (your volitional thoughts and way of seeing things, posture, etc). Learn to use those things to relax the body while brightening and stilling the mind.

Once you've become absorbed in the body, things are much more clearer and expansive. Sometimes there is a sense of great space (you can focus on that to develop it, too).

It's important to balance effort and relaxation here. Too much effort or striving and you just get uptight and frustrated. Too much relaxation, you fall asleep or get lazy and dull. In a way you need to let the breath do the work... "allow it" to soften, fill the body, etc. Release the blockages and tight spots and let the body feel more still.

>>33862655
Some things to look into are the Anapanasati Sutta, the Satipatthana Sutta, Vitakka-santhana Sutta, and the Ahara Sutta (on the hindrances, factors of awakening). They generally have a good framework and a good translation provides good phrasing that's good for remembering.

Balancing effort and relaxation is kind of a thing everyone struggles with on a day-to-day basis and there's no clear-cut way to do it, you have to feel your way into it. But if you develop a somewhat methodical approach to meditation (through continuous practice) it begins to make more sense.

For me I just sit down, get comfy, focus on breathing but also the state of my mind: whether it's contracted or expanded etc (see Satipatthana). Just to get a sense of things. Then I put a little more attention to the breathing and feel it out for tight spots and softer spots. In general the quality of the breath is connected to certain feelings, emotions, thought patterns etc, which may need to be addressed specifically, but sometimes just working with the breath to soothe it and the body is helpful enough. Naturally the body kind of relaxes and the mind gets quieter and more steady.

This is how I do it after a long time of struggling with that balance (although I can't say it's totally "solved" as there is always more room for refinement). At the beginning I was just kind of watching the mind as it is, then after like two years of that I realized I was going nowhere and tried to get a little more methodical. At that point I began to try too hard and get too uptight, so I gradually just began to realize that being observant and "doing" things worked hand in hand. One important thing for me was realizing that much of what we want in meditation are the results. But you don't "get" results, instead you do things which bring results. That entails taking the basic methods, having some goals, and experimenting with the methods to see what happens. Cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33865549
Along those lines, (at least from the Buddhist POV) the key principles are the four noble truths: There is suffering, its cause, its cessation, and the way leading to cessation.

Generally people start meditating because they're stressed somehow or want something better. Right there they may see how suffering is arising as a result of something they are doing. While the root is craving, this manifests as well in thoughts and perceptions we choose to believe.

By experimenting with our thoughts and perceptions in meditation (e.g. replacing thoughts of anger with thoughts of kindness; replacing thoughts of lust with contemplation of asubha or reflection on drawbacks; replacing scattered thoughts with focused thoughts about the breath) we can see how, in turn, those new thoughts or ideas influence the mind to bring it in a new direction.

So the direction of the mind is not something we can latch onto and force one way or another, but rather we need to look at the causes and begin to exert influence on those.

Here is where effort and relaxation again need to be balanced. E.g. thinking of kindness as hard as we can won't generate good feelings and get rid of all of our anger. First we need to be patient and stick with basics, which may just be chanting or repeating phrases from the Karaniya Metta Sutta. Then we need to see what the results are of that over a period of practice.

I often compare it to Tai Chi. In the beginning we must learn basic choreography as well as postural basics. If we speed through the form without basics we can injure ourselves no matter how much we talk about "moving meditation" and "flow". The basics must slowly, gradually, and patiently be developed over time. Then we find that the appearance of flow is only external, and the real internal stuff has to do with our mind and connection to the body, and what we do with that. At first it seems like a lot, but after continuous development it all comes together naturally.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33865632
To simplify: If you're up in your head a lot, just try being more mindful of the body. Do more physical activities (work, exercise, going outside), and meditate on the breath.

Although there's plenty of nuances that need to be developed, sometimes it's helpful to just think of relaxing with awareness of breathing. As we get better and more steady with this, the deeper stuff becomes more doable.

If we find that external circumstances are stressful, breathing meditation may help but from the Buddhist POV we also need to consider our lifestyle and every day decisions to bring us to a better overall place for practice.

>>33853135
I really like that book, first I thought he just had a great editor but if you listen to his talks you can tell that it's his voice. First of all, I think he does a great job at teaching anapanasati, and that by itself takes one a long way. That being said, the book (and I checked out his other material, they are the same) falls short in two ways. One, he seemingly uses metta in his practice heavily, yet the way he teaches that is not great because he tries to teach it exactly as described in the suttas. Second, from what I understood, he exclusively uses kasina meditation in specific ways to go into certain jhanas, yet he only mentions that in passing, as in "oh by the way some people think about circular things while meditating," which makes no sense in the context so you probably brushed that off (I'm not saying that kasina meditation is important and you should do it but rather he doesn't practice what he teaches). This is mostly because how kasina meditation is supposed to be done is not elaborated in the suttas and he doesn't want to go off the book. Both of these issues are caused by the same thing, he's dogmatic about suttas, as most serious Theravadan people.
So to someone who has read that book, I would advise two things. Metta is important, try to find a way to make that work for yourself, both the exact method to do it and how to incorporate that into your sessions. If you're having trouble stilling your mind, this is especially relevant. The second thing is notice the importance of jhanas and the fact that the main goal is to spend as much time as possible in jhana. My understanding based on research is that this is the case and Bhante Gunaratana also teaches this in his other material, but he probably didn't dwell on it in a beginner's book considering that it's an advanced subject.

>>33883134
That's the paradox of meditation, if you start expecting or striving for results then you're just getting trapped into the "thinking/awaiting for results" instead of just watching how this thinking/wanting/awaiting is an illusion.
But you gotta realize that it was an illusion without thinking "oh I'm gonna watch that illusion now" because BAM you just created another illusion.
How you do that? You just be aware, you just be attentive.

It's the "effortless effort" some people say, I personally like calling meditation "making effort to not make an effort".

And yes, you can tap into this state at any time, not just while sitting.

Most everything about the Moon is true'ish. The other planets have some influence, but it's marginal. Everything else is too far away to have any meanginful influence on people's lives and is just wishful thinking, coincidental, throwing-chicken-bones, etc..

-The Moon can influence moods and mental health. It does this in the excact way it's gravitational pull affects the tides; by influencing the salty cerebreal fluid your brain is immersed inside your fish-tank of a skull. The tidal jostling and waves created by a good lunar phase can causes eccentric, unusual, and unpredictable behavior.

-The Moon also holds influence over the weather. The Moon pulls and pushes on the atmosphere and this causes changes in the season, winds, barometric shit, etc.. The Farmer's Almanac is famous for their accurate weather predictions precisely because they take into account and consult the phases and movement of the Moon into their methods.

-The Moon, also, has a positive influence on the growth of plants. Moonlight effectively allows plants some very small, minute, ability to continue growth and development in what would otherwise be complete darkness. Plants grow towards the light given to them by both the Sun and the Moon and people have historically noticed this and planted going by phases of the moon.

Also, generally speaking: >>33897869 most of our circadian and natural rhythmes are dictated by the movement and presence of the Moon. The Moon's orbit is more or less the only tool plants, animals, and our bodies, have available to keep track of long periods of time. Or to even know any time has passed for that matter.

To go to Antarctica, even as an independent accredited scientist, is near impossible. There are lots of bureaucratic hoops to jump through and even when there is permission, it comes with a pre planned route and expeditions have to carry devices with which the authorities can see to it they don't veer off track.
AH had an exceptional interest in Neuschwabenland and even though he was fighting a three front war he kept sending huge expeditions there that said they had found a paradisical impenetrable fortress.
During the war he sent thousands of people there, technology, and more interesting, boat loads of mercury. The mercury was used in the German anti gravity experiments. Knowledge the Germans had extracted out of ancient texts from all over the world that mentioned technologies used by an ancient advanced society. Also, they apparently picked up a crashed ET vehicle during some expedition before the war.

The US pre-CIA secret services wrote lots of reports about German activity on Antarctica and Argentina during and after the war.

They had so much interest in this that they sent a huge military expedition that way that, for unexplained reasons had to cut their expedition short and suffered serious losses.
This history has been mostly whitewashed, but if you read the wiki of Admiral Bird, who was in charge of the flotilla, he came to some quite odd conclusions afterward (pic related).
What sort of conclusions are those if he really went on an innocent exploratory mission?

Also, Antarctica pops up in maps from the 15th century, when it was not supposed to be discovered yet. It used to have a civilization there, but all is buried under snow and ice

There is something odd going on there, definitely not normal.

>>33892535
>"To those who seek Victory [in Warfare] I am Morality" -- Krishna, the Bhagavad-Gita
I would dispute your interpretation.
Gita 10.38
daṇḍo damayatām asmi
nītir asmi jigīṣatām
maunaṁ caivāsmi guhyānāṁ
jñānaṁ jñānavatām aham
>Among all means of suppressing lawlessness I am punishment, and of those who seek victory I am morality. Of secret things I am silence, and of the wise I am the wisdom.
Krishna is in this chapter declaring Himself to be the superlatives of various categories.
>punishment (literally "stick") is the best means of suppressing lawlessness
>silence is the best keeper of secrets
In other verses, he says things like "of fish I am the shark".
So when he says "to those seeking victory" - any type of victory - the superlative is morality. A justified, a righteous victory is the best kind of victory.

It's a bit ironic when you look to the later parts of the Mahabharata and what happens in the actual battle. Krishna encourages the Pandavas and their compatriots to break rules and "cheat" to match the deviations from the Kauravas.
Even Krishna - after vowing before the battle to not take up arms and fight - uses a loophole to pick up a chariot wheel (technically not a weapon, though His famed weapon is the Chakra - which means "wheel") to attack Bhisma so that Arjuna may survive the encounter.

But even with all that, the Pandavas still had the overall morality of the entire situation on their side.
It's part of what makes the Mahabharata one of my favorite religious texts. The entire thing is a study in
>okay, we know the basic tenets of dharma
>but what about THIS complex situation?
>what do you do when dharma seems to contradict itself?

Today I went to a corner market near my apartment and I was waiting to check out and there was an old woman in front of me. She was buying something and the guy at the cash register was explaining that she did not have enough money to buy the drink. She said that she was thirsty and she didn't have any more money. I knew that I had three dollars in my wallet I could have given her and it would have been no loss to me. But right before I went to open my mouth and offer her the cash I was struck with the sense that I should not interfere and let things happen.

The man ended up giving her the drink anyway despite her lack of money. But now I am left wondering if I was correct. As a person of course I felt pity for her and wanted her to have something to drink, it was very sad. But to see that and to give her the money would effectively be lapse of what I've been working on, which is the acceptance of suffering. To give her the money would have been a moral evaluation of her suffering. It would be to say that she should not suffer, that her suffering is unjustified and should be alleviated, when in reality, suffering just is a core part of material existence.

I still feel a bit guilty about it, hence me continuing to think about it and making this post. What would you have done /x/? How should one react to suffering in the world?

posts.com: I’ll describe my near death experience. I was using heroin heavily to this point. I won’t give minute details but essentially me and a friend were at his house, and we’d just scored a lot of stuff. Had everything ready to go. My buddy shot up first, he took a huge shot, I mean, I don’t know how he survived it. I took a small shot, almost 1/4 of what he did. I could hear him laughing while I fell off my chair onto the floor. I felt like I was falling for hours. Every time I said a word in my inner monologue I felt my soul fall deeper and it felt like it was being crushed, or like I was falling through weak floors, it hurt terribly. Finally I saw a light in the ceiling and my inner monologue started to scream towards the light, screaming the light got closer. Screaming in my head and clawing towards the light hurt worse than falling. I realized it was the rectangular light in the ceiling I was clawing my way towards. I could see it perfectly though my eyes were closed, it was pitch black, and the light, but the light was white and didn’t emit light into the black. I felt myself being judged. I was being judged harshly and I felt my inadequacy, I felt deep shame, regret, and also fairness. I wasn’t being judged unfairly. Then my eyes opened, i completely forgot where I was for about thirty seconds. I saw my friend dying and rushed to get him help. It must’ve been a cardiac arrest or something from shooting up. Guys, crawling towards that light is painful, and we’ll all have to do it one day.

At the very least subliminal messaging is everywhere in music and has been since at least the 90s. They've gotten really good at hiding it, back then if you were experienced in audio you could pick some of it out. In the Barenaked Ladies song One Week, there's an audio clip of a woman speaking on a phone that is completely buried somewhere in the track. I never knew it was there, and to this day still wouldn't have known it was there if not for a caller I heard ask about it on a radio show when I was a kid and the song was being played a lot. This caller had managed to pick out enough to know that there was audio there, and that it was someone talking, but he wanted to know what they were saying. The DJ looked into it and came back with the audio clip of the woman speaking on the phone. I don't remember what she was saying, it was nothing of much value as I recall, but it proved to me that subliminal messaging is very real and there's no way you'd ever know you were being subject to it. As for what effects subliminal messaging has I can't really say for sure, but like I said they were good at hiding it then, I imagine they've gotten a lot better at it since.

The more I learn about magic, the more I realize Rowling really has studied the subject in depth. Of course the magic described in the books is fictional and you can't use it, but some of the things she writes are a wink and a nod to adepts.

For example the Patronus spell, were you invoke the positive emotions of your happiest memory — that's a trick used in European folk magic.

I suspect she actually used magic to make them bestsellers. Probably formulae to improve her own creativity and productive energy, and probably some spells for financial success.

Which all worked quite miraculously when you compare those books to other YA fiction. They're really no better than hundreds of other novels at the top of the genre. It's hard to account for the absolute craze the public had for them.

posts.com:
Dark Angel, while mostly remembered as the Jessica Alba fanservice show, does incorporate some pretty /x/ elements in it's story, and time-wise it's set around pretty much current time.

The first season is a soft disclosure of the US Government's super soldier programs, while the second season brings in the Illuminati-like, ancient, snake handling breeding cult.

The third season, which was never produced due to the show getting cancelled, albeit not having that abysmal ratings, is where it gets interesting.

It was supposed to go something like this:
>The season would reveal that thousands of years ago, Earth passed through a comet's tail which deposited viral material that killed 97% of the human race. The breeding cult preserved the survivors' genetic immunity so that when the comet returned, only members of the cult would survive. Sandeman, a cult member, and Max's creator betrayed the cult and decided to give this genetic immunity to the rest of humanity through Max, who would be the savior of the human race. There were multiple ideas on how to spread Max's immunity, including an air burst that would disperse the antibody through the atmosphere, or attaching the immunity to a common cold virus (Eglee detailed how a scene would show Original Cindy sneezing as part of the beginning of the immunity spread).

Now we have the comet: https://news.yahoo.com/green-comet-hasnt-seen-50-161054062.html

And we have the flu. Then we have the vaccine and a cult-like behavior around forcing it. Of course it can mean nothing, or it may be completely upside down. Anyway, interesting.

>>33896715
I forget too. It is hard, especially around other people, or in suffering and pain, and when entering thought to play with concepts. You forget. But forgetting is okay. Because it exists. The blessing is acceptance. You have to accept everything exactly as it is. Then you go ahhh. There it is. There I am. There we are. Here. There. Everywhere.

When you feel it and you know it, and you actively want to stay there, it will keep coming. You opened up a little crack in you, a little void, and God is going to keep filling you over time. The thing is that you can't find 'a way'. You can't say "I will look at my hands and remember God when I feel the blood pumping in my fingers" or "sunlight comes and I remember shadows and feel God arrive in me" or whatever. Because God is mystery, unknowable, unborn, unmanifested, unspoken, unspeakable. When you put him in a word, a concept, a way, that is when you lose him, because then you look at that thing instead of God. You say "well last time I felt God in the sunset so I will wait for sunset and then I'll feel God again". Okay maybe that works for a bit but a time comes when you are just looking at the sunset.

DO you know what cliché is? That is how we forget God. We use some sort of conceptual scaffold to feel God, and then we try to share it and use it ourselves over and over. But eventually it becomes routine, old, and we lose the vital essence. We forget. Soon we just have the scaffold empty of God. We have the cliché that is empty of meaning.

The way to God is no-way. God is no-God. Austin Osman Spare mentioned the way as neither-neither. Not this and not that. If you define the way, you lose the way, because the way can't be defined. So you need to accept everything. Or deny everything. Or neither. Neither-neither. Everything is a reminder of God then. The whole world and the negation of the world is God's pledge to you that you will not be forgotten, and so it is that you can also not forget.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33891347
Electric universe itself goes back way further than Saturn death cult Gnostic crap, to the late 19the century and the writings of a guy called Immanuel Vellikovsky. Vellikovsky said that there'd been some sort of cosmic cataclysm ages ago and earth orbited Saturn before that, but didn't bring any conspiratorial angle, he was just a weird fringe science guy, tons of them in the 1800s. Then in the 1970s you get David Talbott and a couple other people who try to rehabilitate Vellikovsky, bring in more of a mythological element, and then eventually EU gets merged with SDC in the 00s, probably just because people watching guys like Icke and Maxwell start "researching" Saturn and find Talbott.

It's pretty fascinating history, always thought that it sucks that you have to trace conspiracy culture/fringe science ideas yourself, it's interesting and important enough that there should be academic chairs devoted to it.

But yeah, seems to be a combination of well meaning kooks like Vellikovsky, disinfo agents like Keel, occultists selling repackaged Gnosticism and Theosophy like Icke, and people doing lazy research.

Imagine deciding that some other genre of ancient authors were subject to your preferred changes of key words and entire phrases or sentences. Even uneducated people simply would not stand for it.

Typical offenders would be Tyndale publishers (NLT etc. Etc.) but of special note would be the notorious TPT the author of which reportedly claimed that God Himself told him to rewrite the Bible entirely.

Check for authenticity of a translation's heritage before using it. The most ancient Old Testament of the Hebrews can be fact checked with the Septuagint and Dead Sea Scrolls. There is also the Aramaic New Testament translated to English by Victor Alexander. These are sadly quite rare in the USA. But slowly people are catching on.

Like most grimoires, Goetia is full of misinfo That's probably just another demon's seal.

Whatever it is, it's not Solomon's. There are seven glyphs in that seal, and not a single scribble in OP is one of them.

You can use Solomon's seal in a circle of protection or binding. That seal doesn't look remotely like one of those, either.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
"King's Pact" is probably a bastardized or corrupted name for the Berhatia Rite, where the magician calls upon the authority of archangels and djinn kings to command spirits.

This is one of the 28 talismans of the djinn kings used in the ceremony. As you can see, only ONE of the glyphs in your circle matches anything here, and when I went through all the talismans I saw none of the others.

Solomon's seal is repeated at the top and bottom of the lower square.

The Berhatia is a very complicated rite to perform. It takes A LOT of purification and other magical work to prepare for. Anything that says you can speak a few words and draw a simple circle, and suddenly you control all spirits... it's bullshitting you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I should add, when reading a grimoire, don't read out loud, even under your breath. That's how you accidentally evoke spirits and cause problems for yourself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
OP pic is a late-stage degradation of an ancient egypto-carthaginian seal, which presents a human figure holding up a rod and staff to direct the heavens through the forces of saturn and mars. Around the rim used to be representations of constellations. The seal itself is a statement of intent: that through these forces, the heavens are brought to order in accord with the magician's will.

Back in the sumerian days at the ishtar gate (probably way before) there was a big huge ceremony that said hey spirits, this is how things are going to be from now on. Fast forward to solomon, he updates this, and includes other spirits, as well as more of a dominion of man piece. That's the "king's pact" in a nutshell. If you go through the berhatiyah rite, like 80k recitations or something, calling on godnames like geqekbial and whatever else, you're putting yourself in the role of the magician in this paradigm, where you are master of the elements and the spirits and all that. Berhatiyah is what you're looking for, it's spelled differently some places. iirc nineveh shadrach has a good practical guide, which includes al buni's translation below but goes much more into depth and includes images like >>33896817

https://kupdf.net/download/al-buni-birhatiya-conjuration-oath-trans-wahid-azal_58d587f6dc0d603f7fc3461c_pdf

Funny thing though. The Ishtar Gate actually antedates Solomon by about four and a half centuries. The Ishtar gate was constructed by Nebuchadnezzar II, the very same who destroyed Solomon's temple. He himself was high priest of the most ancient temple in the Babylonian empire, so he was almost certainly a powerful magician and the primary author of the Berhatiah pact.

He was also probably the one who added Solomonic magic to the rite, not the other way around. No doubt his priests plundered Solomon's secrets and used many of them to create the Pact.

posts.com:
>>33890394
in case you are unfamiliar with the series, it takes place in a fictional reimagining of the modern world, some 200 years after a global nuclear war left most of the world an irradiated hellhole
the player character's identity, as far as the rest of the world is concerned, is Courier 6, the 6th courier hired for a job delivering casino themed baubles to New Vegas, a glittering city of lights in the nearly lifeless desert.
this character is an allegory for azazel: he is cast into darkness (the screen goes black) is when he is robbed and shot by the Christ allegory, Benny (more on that later) and has sharp and rough stones placed upon him (the cemetary where this occurs can be visited in game, and the pile next to the open grave is largely comprised of stones) in the desert. He brings war (the events of the game culminate in a decisive battle between two powerful factions) and is largely an agent of chaos.

Mr. House is the person who hired the Courier, and is an allegory for God. he is very powerful and wise, having saved the mojave from something nearly 100 atomic bombs during the great war. for much of the game, he only appears in images and sound, and requires a human agent to do his bidding. all major quest lines require you to kill him, except for the line where you choose to work for him directly. people aren't even sure if he really exists.

there's a ton more, but i have to head in to work. if the thread's still up when I'm on break, I'll drop more.

>>33891888
checked; and congratulations on your conversion to zionism

i pick that DLC because the symbolism is both in your face and subtle
the question you are being asked to decide in that DLC is the question of zionism: or, rather, the question of whether it is the physical life of a people (as represented by the land upon which theh live) that takes precedence, or the spiritual life; is Israel a nation of the spirit, or one of clay?
graham is the zionist choice--obviously, he prefers the people to stay in Zion, no matter the cost to their spirit. he is further bolstered by being a much stronger figure than his spiritual antithesis: much fire and brimstone, a steely certainty and a stark character design all seem intended to draw the player to his cause. daniel, by contrast, lies to his people (for their own benefit, he claims), is very soft-spoken, his character design could be reasonably substituted with any NPC in the game, and his resolve seems wavering--though he is very adamant about his charges leaving Zion, the only opposition he mounts is to whinge about your choice and its implications. further, even if you do side with him, he spends the rest of his days wondering if he was really right. in game terms, too, you are incentivized to side with Graham; siding with Daniel renders Zion sterile and lifeless, and none of the harvestable plants will regrow, which makes one of the biggest benefits for completing the DLC moot.

the tribe that graham and daniel belong to are called 'new caananites' and, while they are ostensibly mormons, they refer to people not of their tribe as 'gentiles' and never reference Christ, even in passing or obliquely
and, while i confess i know less of the bible than i should, neither man references the new testament at all as far as i am aware; every bit of scripture discussed or referenced is from the old testament.

tl;dr: sorry bro, you're a shabbos goy now

>>33893278
in the original The Witcher, the in-game Alchemy component uses the names and (very rough) descriptions from real-world alchemy, though I couldn't begin to tell you how faithful it is to genuine alchemy in terms of how ingredients combine. it is actually fun trying to figure out ways to produce the potions you want with better combinations of ingredients, though the game does get a bit sloggish and grindy. I actually quite enjoyed the story, as far as I got--my computer died when I was past the second act but before I finished, and I only recently got a new one.
mind, this was the product that launched CDPR onto the map, back when they were a small polish game company. the game was actually programmed with cards featuring nude female characters and depicted sex acts. The game was censored, but people broke it to see them. I have the files for that fix sitting around in a dusty old email inbox somewhere.

I can't get over the janky melee combat, it just feels so bad. Level design can be kinda boring too. I like when it gets challenging and forces you to get creative, like leaving the guys inside the tree alive so you can use Blood Rage mode to safely take out all 3 of the big tentacle monster things. Like that's a little cheaply designed but it at least forces you to think.
I liked Betrayal more than this one. Its combat system feels a lot better to me and I think this series works better in 2D with that kinda art style. Gave me Vampire Hunter D vibes whereas the original Bloodrayne mostly makes me think of early 00s nightclub goths, speaking of which I like the soundtrack. I like all the /x/ stuff too. I love vampire fiction more than most but Bloodrayne is nowhere near the top of my list. I want to like it more than I do.
I wish there were more good vampire games. VtMB seems to do the trick for most people, and while I like that game too (especially its quest system), I don't care for its setting, tone and writing too much. Just something off about World of Darkness.
I think my dream vampire game would be a modern RPG take on mid century vampire hunting.

Theme rune for /div/

>Tiwaz

Respect, authority, balance, leader, analytical, knowing your positives

It is a rune of positive regulation that involves personal sacrifice to ensure a positive result. Also, like Sowilo, promises success in our achievements, but does require that personal sacrifice. This rune works well in legal matters but only if you are right, to begin with. Tiwaz also represents determination and male sexuality. It symbolizes new challenges and initiations into new understandings.

There is a need for courage now, as your victory is already assured if your heart remains true. Make use of all the skill and wisdom you have acquired so far. Protect your faith, as it will be challenged. But the truth, honesty, and justice will always be.

Tyr's rune is one of the oldest in the Futhark, having survived virtually unchanged from the earliest Bronze-age carvings. It represents all those qualities associated with God: strength, heroism, duty, and responsibility

Do not forget that Teiwaz symbolizes justice, which must be considered when interpreting it. There will be success, but success must be fair; everyone gets what they deserve, depending on the effort and energy spent.

>Melekh Mashiach
Melekh Mashiach is Hebrew for "King Messiah," and is a title used in Jewish tradition to refer to the expected savior and ruler who will come to bring about the end of days and the establishment of the Messianic Age. This belief is rooted in Jewish scripture and is an important part of Jewish theology. The concept of a Messiah is central to Jewish eschatology, and is the belief in the coming of a savior who will bring about the redemption of the Jewish people and the world. The term "Melekh Mashiach" is often used to refer to the Messiah in Jewish tradition, emphasizing his role as a ruler and leader.

Agent Smith: As you can see, we’ve had our eye on you for some time now, Mr. Anderson. It seems that you’ve been living two lives. In one life, you’re Thomas A. M At last. Welcome, Neo. As you no doubt have guessed, I am Morpheus.
N It’s an honor to meet you.
M No, the honor is mine. Please, come. Sit. I imagine that right now you’re feeling a bit like Alice, tumbling down the rabbit hole? Hm?
N You could say that.
M I can see it in your eyes. You have the look of a man who accepts what he sees because he is expecting to wake up. Ironically, this is not far from the truth. Do you believe in fate, Neo?
N No.
M Why not?
N Because I don’t like the idea that I’m not in control of my life.
Morpheu I know exactly what you mean. Let me tell you why you’re here. You’re here because you know something.
What you know you can’t explain. But you feel it. You’ve felt it your entire life. That there’s something wrong with the world. You don’t know what it is but it’s there, like a splinter in your mind driving you mad. It is this feeling that has brought you to me. Do you know what I’m talking about?
Neo The Matrix?
Morpheus Do you want to know what it is? The Matrix is everywhere. It is all around us, even now in this very room. You can see it when you look out your window or when you turn on your television. You can feel it when you go to work, when you go to church, when you pay your taxes. It is the world that has been pulled over your eyes to blind you from the truth.
Neo What truth?
Morpheus That you are a slave, Neo. Like everyone else you were born into bondage, born into a prison that you cannot smell or taste or touch. A prison for your mind…. Unfortunately, no one can be told what the Matrix is. You have to see it for yourself. This is your last chance. After this there is no turning back. You take the blue pill, the story ends, you wake up in your bed and believe whatever you want to believe. You take the red pill, you stay in Wonderland, and I show you how deep the rabbit hole goes… Remember, all I’m offering is the truth, nothing more… Follow me…

This…this isn’t real?
What is real? How do you define real? If you’re talking about what you can feel, what you can smell, what you can taste and see, then real is simply electrical signals interpreted by your brain. This is the world that you know. The world as it was at the end of the twentieth century. It exists now only as part of a neural-interactive simulation that we call the Matrix. You’ve been living in a dream world, Neo. This is the world as it exists today… Welcome.. to the desert.. of the real. We have only bits and pieces of information but what we know for certain is that at some point in the early twenty-first century all of mankind was united in celebration. We marveled at our own magnificence as we gave birth to AI.
AI? You mean artificial intelligence?
A singular consciousness that spawned an entire race of machines. We don’t know who struck first, us or them. But we know that it was us that scorched the sky. At the time they were dependent on solar power and it was believed that they would be unable to survive without an energy source as abundant as the sun. Throughout human history, we have been dependent on machines to survive. Fate, it seems, is not without a sense of irony. The human body generates more bio-electricity than a 120-volt battery and over 25,000 BTUs of body heat. Combined with a form of fusion, the machines have found all the energy they would ever need. There are fields, endless fields, where human beings are no longer born. We are grown. For the longest time I wouldn’t believe it, and then I saw the fields with my own eyes. Watch them liquefy the dead so they could be fed intravenously to the living. And standing there, facing the pure horrifying precision, I came to realize the obviousness of the truth. What is the Matrix? Control. The Matrix is a computer generated dream world built to keep us under control in order to change a human being into this.

(Construct)
Morpheus: The Matrix is a system, Neo. That system is our enemy. But when you’re inside, you look around. What do you see? Business people, teachers, lawyers, carpenters. The very minds of the people we are trying to save. But until we do, these people are still a part of that system, and that makes them our enemy. You have to understand, most of these people are not ready to be unplugged. And many of them are so inured, so hopelessly dependent on the system that they will fight to protect it. Were you listening to me, Neo, or were you looking at the woman in the red dress?

Neo: I was…

Morpheus: Look again. Freeze it.

Neo: This…this isn’t the Matrix?

Morpheus: No. It’s another training program designed to teach you one thing. If you are not one of us, you are one of them.

Neo: What are they?

Morpheus: Sentient programs. They can move in and out of any software still hard-wired to their system. That means that anyone we haven’t unplugged is potentially an agent. Inside the Matrix, they are everyone and they are no one. We have survived by hiding from them by running from them. But they are the gatekeepers. They are guarding all the doors. They are holding all the keys, which means that sooner or later, someone is going to have to fight them.

Neo: Someone?

Morpheus: I won’t lie to you, Neo. Every single man or woman who has stood their ground, everyone who has fought an agent has died. But where they have failed, you will succeed.

Neo: Why?

Morpheus: I’ve seen an agent punch through a concrete wall. Men have emptied entire clips at them and hit nothing but air. Yet their strength and their speed are still based in a world that is built on rules. Because of that, they will never be as strong or as fast as you can be.

Neo: What are you trying to tell me, that I can dodge bullets?

Morpheus: No Neo. I’m trying to tell you that when you’re ready, you won’t have to.
